S2095-4956(22)00692-1 10.1016/j.jechem.2022.12.026 Science Press and Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences Fig. 1 Schematic illustration on the preparation of NPPH and control samples (a) and characterizations of NPPH sample (b-e): (b) XRD patterns (together with control samples), (c) SEM image, (d) HRTEM image, and (e) HAADF-STEM image and the corresponding EDS mapping of the NPPH. Fig. 2 Electrochemical OER performances of NPPH and control samples: (a) OER polarization curves under a scan rate of 1 mV s−1, (b) overpotential at different current densities, (c) Tafel slopes, (d) Nyquist plots measured at an overpotential of 300 mV. The inset is the equivalent circuit diagram. Fig. 3 DFT calculations of OER on the NPPH-O catalyst: (a) surface oxidized NPPH heterostructure, (b) local structural configurations of intermediates on NPPH-O heterostructure (the spheres in cyan, red, dark green, and pink denote the H, O, Ni, and P atoms, respectively), (c) calculated free energy profiles for OER on the NPPH-O heterostructure with Ni2P-O and Ni12P5-O control samples as comparison, and (d) comparison of partial density of states (PDOS) and d-band centers of Ni on the samples of Ni2P-O, Ni12P5-O and NPPH-O heterostructure. Fig. 4 Schematic illustration on the preparation of Ir/NPPH (a) as well as its structural characterizations and OER performances: (b) aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM image (single dispersed Ir atoms are remarked by yellow circles), (c) HAADF-STEM image and the corresponding EDS elemental mapping, (d) OER polarization curves of Ir/NPPH and control samples at a scan rate of 1 mV s−1 in 1 M KOH, (e) overpotential at different current densities, (f) Tafel slopes of Ir/NPPH and control samples, and (g) chronopotentiometric curves for Ir/NPPH and Ir/CFP (without iR correction). Fig. 5 High-resolution XPS spectrum and XAS analysis of Ir/NPPH and control samples. (a) XPS spectra of Ir 4f, (b) Ni 2p, (c) P 2p, XANES spectra at the (d) Ir L3-edge, (e) Ni k-edge, and (f) EXAFS spectra at Ir L3-edge. Fig. 6 Structural models for the DFT calculation on the Ir/NPPH-O (a) and Ir/CFP (b) as well as their local structural configurations of intermediates during the OER on the Ir/NPPH-O (c) and Ir/CFP (d), and (e) comparison of calculated free energy profiles for OER on the Ir/NPPH-O, Ir/CFP, and NPPH-O catalysts. One dimensional nickel phosphide polymorphic heterostructure as carbon-free functional support loading single-atom iridium for promoted electrocatalytic water oxidation Rashid Mehmood a b 1 Guifa Long c 1 Wenjun Fan a Mingrun Li a Lifang Liu a b Fuxiang Zhang a ⁎ a StateKey Laboratory of Catalysis, iChEM, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China StateKey Laboratory of Catalysis, iChEM, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy Dalian 116023 Liaoning China StateKey Laboratory of Catalysis, iChEM, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China b Center of Materials Science and Optoelectronics Engineering, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China Universityof Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China Universityof Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China c GuangxiKey Laboratory of Chemistry and Engineering of Forest Products, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Guangxi Minzu University, Nanning 530008, Guangxi, China GuangxiKey Laboratory of Chemistry and Engineering of Forest Products School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Guangxi Minzu University Nanning 530008 China GuangxiKey Laboratory of Chemistry and Engineering of Forest Products, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Guangxi Minzu University, Nanning 530008, Guangxi, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Graphical abstract 1D NPPH heterostructure was developed to exhibit efficient alkaline water oxidation catalyst as well as carbon-free functional support of loading single atom catalyst, based on which remarkable synergetic promotion effect on the water oxidation can be obtained. Although conducting materials such as carbon nanotube and carbon fiber paper (CFP) have been extensively employed as support of electrocatalytic active sites, most of them are of poor catalytic functionality by themselves and undesirable stability during strong acid/alkaline environments or oxidation process. Here we report a novel one-dimensional (1D) nickel phosphide polymorphic heterostructure (denoted as NPPH) to work as one effective carbon-free functional support for loading of single-atom Ir water oxidation electrocatalyst. Specifically, the NPPH composed of both Ni12P5 and Ni2P phases is not only active for robust alkaline water oxidation but also is of good stability and hydrophilicity for favorable loading of single-atom dispersed iridium. The NPPH supported single-atom Ir electrocatalyst (Ir/NPPH) is found to exhibit remarkably superior water oxidation activity with respect to the NPPH itself or CFP supported single-atom Ir catalyst (Ir/CFP), demonstrating the synergetic promotion effect between NPPH and single-atom Ir catalyst. Furthermore, the NPPH supported single-atom Ir catalyst can bear alkaline water oxidation for over 120 h at current density of 50 mA cm−2. The NPPH developed here is expected as functional support to composite with other water oxidation catalysts, as may be an alternative strategy of developing highly efficient carbon-free electrocatalysts. Keywords Oxygen evolution reaction Single atom catalyst Nickel phosphide Heterostructure One-dimensional 1 Introduction Development of water oxidation catalysts (WOCs) has inspired extensive interest in consideration of its great significance in the fields such as water electrolysis, metal-air batteries, and CO2 electrolysis and so on [1–5]. Generally, the efforts of developing efficient WOCs can be coarsely divided into two areas: one is to reduce the content of scarce noble metals (i.e., IrO2, RuO2) by preparing single-atom dispersed catalysts [6–9], and the other is to investigate the catalysts based on non-noble metals for efficient and stable oxygen evolution reactions (OER) [10,11]. One of their most common features is to deposit the active phase on the surface of conducting supports with one or two dimensional orientation for efficient electron transfer and relatively large surface areas for high dispersion of active sites, among which the carbon-based materials like carbon fiber paper (CFP) have been popularly investigated [12–14]. However, the carbon-based support itself is normally of poor activity and stability for acid/alkaline water oxidation, and its surface is also shortage of abundant groups or hydrophilicity for further anchoring of active sites [15,16]. Accordingly, it is highly desirable to develop alternative carbon-free supports with good conductivity and abundant surface groups or good hydrophilicity. Recently, transition metal phosphide-based electrocatalysts (TMPs) have been widely reported to exhibit excellent functionalities of OER and/or hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [17–21]. Furthermore, their electronic structures and chemisorption capacities can be easily modulated to enhance the catalytic performances by various strategies such as heteroatom doping [22–24], interface and surface engineering [25,26], nanostructure design [27], and construction of heterogeneous interface [28] etc. Among the TMPs-based electrocatalysts, nickel phosphide is one of the mostly investigated representative catalysts [29,30], which contains abundant metal-rich (e.g., Ni2P, Ni12P5, and Ni5P4) or phosphorus-rich (e.g., NiP2 and NiP3) phases [31]. This renders it to become easy in fabricating polymorphic heterostructure that has been recently demonstrated for excellent modulation into the structure as well as performances [32]. As similar to other metal phosphides [33], the nickel phosphide materials also owns such advantages as high conductivity, abundant surface defects for single-atom anchoring, tunable microstructure and surface hydrophilicity. This means that the nickel phosphide owns both functionality of WOCs and feature of conducting support, which renders us to reasonably expect that the nickel phosphide may be a good candidate to become alternative OER-functional support compared to the popularly reported carbon-based supports. Herein, we report one novel one-dimensional (1D) nickel phosphide polymorphic heterostructure (NPPH) composed of both Ni12P5 and Ni2P phases, which was prepared by adopting a simple hydrothermal treatment on the commercially available nickel foam (NF) and subsequent phosphorization. The 1D NPPH in situ grown on the surface of NF is not only highly active and robust for alkaline OER by itself, but also favorable as support for loading of single-atom Ir due to its special 1D structure and abundant surface defects. Here the 1D NPPH can be understood as the functional support, in contrast to traditional carbon-based supports shortage of water oxidation functionality. As benefited from water oxidation ability of NPPH itself, the NPPH supported single-atom Ir catalyst (Ir/NPPH) exhibits superior OER performance to the single-atom Ir catalyst deposited on carbon-based supports (i.e., CFP), demonstrating the synergetic effect between the iridium and NPPH catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Pretreatment of NF Prior to the preparation of catalysts, the NF was first cut into 3 cm × 3 cm pieces, which were then slightly pressed to make it thinner. The surface oxide layer and organic molecules on NF were removed by sonication in 3 M HCl for 30 min, followed by sonication in deionized water, ethanol, and acetone for 30 min, respectively. Subsequently, the resulting NF pieces were dried at 60 °C for 24 h in a vacuum oven. 2.2 Surface roughening of NF Surface roughening of NF was conducted on the pretreated NF by a stepwise two-step hydrothermal method [34]. Firstly, the NF pieces were transferred into a stainless steel autoclave (50 mL) containing 30 mL of 1 mM of (NH4)2HPO4 aqueous solution. The autoclave was sealed and maintained at 180 °C for 12 h. Afterwards, the sample was taken out and washed with DI water several times and dried at 60 °C for overnight in a vacuum oven. Subsequently, the obtained NF was further transferred into stainless steel autoclave (50 mL) containing 35 mL of 100 mM KOH aqueous solution and treated at 120 °C for 5 h. Through the two-step treatment, the NF could become coarser and more defective. The resulting sample was labeled as r-NF. 2.3 Synthesis of 1D NPPH heterostructure on NF electrode The 1D NPPH heterostructure on NF was synthesized by the phosphorization method, using the r-NF as both the conductive support and the nickel source. Typically, the NaH2PO2·H2O was mixed with r-NF by 10:1 weight ratio and then the ceramic boat carrying the sample was heated in a N2 atmosphere-surrounded furnace at 275 °C for 2 h with an increasing rate of 5 °C min−1. After cooling down to room temperature, the sample was washed with deionized water several times and dried in a vacuum oven at room temperature overnight. For simplicity, the as-prepared electrode was denoted as NPPH. By adjusting the phosphorization temperature (250–400 °C), the Ni12P5/Ni2P catalysts with different molar ratio of Ni12P5 to Ni2P could be modulated in the region of 0–1. Meanwhile, single phases of Ni12P5 and Ni2P were synthesized as control samples by using the temperatures of 250 and 400 °C, respectively. 2.4 Synthesis of Ir/NPPH and Ir/CFP Typically, a calculated amount of K2IrCl6 was dissolved into a mixture of ethanol and water, which was then drop-casted onto the surface of NPPH electrode and heated at 70 °C for 1 h. The obtained catalyst is denoted as Ir/NPPH, and the loading content of Ir on the Ir/NPPH catalyst is determined by ICP analysis. As for discussion, the control sample Ir/CFP was similarly prepared by depositing Ir on the surface of CFP instead of NPPH. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 a depicts a simple illustration on the synthesis of 1D NPPH on the NF, during which the step-wise treatment of (NH4)2HPO4 and KOH is expected to make the NF surface become rough to create abundant defects [34]. By tuning the phosphorization temperature in the final step (details in experimental section), the NPPH polymorphic heterostructure composed of both Ni12P5 and Ni2P, or single phase of Ni12P5 and Ni2P as control samples can be prepared. As demonstrated by the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns given in Fig. 1b, their diffraction peaks are in good accordance with that in the card of Ni12P5 (JCPDS NO. 22–1190) or Ni2P (JCPDS NO. 03–0953) phase. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image of the NPPH catalyst exhibits a 1D nanorod morphology with needle-like structure (Fig. 1c). It has been demonstrated that the unique structure with curvature tip may enhance the electronic conductivity and enhance the local electric field to induce enhanced concentration of hydroxide ions (OH–) at the active sites and promote the intrinsic activity [35,36]. The enhanced conductivity renders it to be a good support as well. Comparatively, similar 1D structural morphology with needle-like tip is observed for the single phase of Ni2P or Ni12P5 (Fig. S1). The local structure of NPPH catalyst was further examined by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) to confirm the formation of the polymorphic heterostructure between Ni12P5 and Ni2P with a clear interface (Fig. 1d), where the different phases can be judged by the d values of their distinct crystal faces. The high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images and the corresponding energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping display the uniform distribution of Ni and P elements throughout the 1D polymorphic structure (Fig. 1e). Water oxidation functionality of the NPPH were first evaluated by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) technique in O2-saturated 1 M KOH electrolyte using a standard three-electrode setup and the Hg/HgO reference electrode was calibrated to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) to ensure the accuracy of the results (Fig. S2). As seen in Fig. 2 a, the 1D NPPH heterostructure electrode can remarkably drive the alkaline water oxidation to show an overpotential of only 254 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 (η 10), which is comparatively lower than that of the Ni2P (278 mV) or Ni12P5 (288 mV) control sample, and even lower than that of the benchmark RuO2 (275 mV). The outstanding OER functionality of NPPH heterostructure can be further reflected by comparison of overpotentials at other current densities such as 10, 50, 100, and 200 mA cm−2 (Fig. 2b), weight-normalized (Fig. S3) and the electrochemical active surface area ECSAs-normalized results (Fig. S4), respectively. It is worthy of being noted that the alkaline OER activity of NPPH heterostructure in this work is also superior to that recently reported nickel Phosphide electrode (Table S1). Strikingly, the 1D NPPH heterostructure also exhibits extraordinary alkaline water oxidation stability, as is not only supported by the no obviously decreased current density in the experimental region of 200 hours (Fig. S5, non-iR correction), but also confirmed by the no obvious crystal structural change of samples before and after the long-term OER test (Fig. S6). Moreover, the surface state of NPPH sample after the OER process was also analyzed by the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Fig. S7). The XPS spectrum of Ni 2p revealed that before the OER process, small characteristic peak at 852.54 eV can be attributed to the Ni–P bond and the peak at 855.89 eV is probably due to the oxidized Ni species resulting from the superficial oxidation of NPPH via Ni-PO x formation [37] and after the OER process, the Ni–P peak (852.54 eV) diminished significantly because of the formation of more NiOP surface oxidation layer. Similarly, XPS spectrum of P 2p showed that the negligible Ni-P peak (129.3 eV) also disappears after the OER process further illustrates the NiOP bond formation at the surface of the catalyst, which may promote the proton-coupled electron transfer process for OER catalytic activity [38]. Compared with the control samples of Ni2P and Ni12P5, the superior water oxidation performance on the NPPH heterostructure can be mainly ascribed to the integration of its faster reaction kinetics with lower Tafel slope (Fig. 2c), faster electron/charge transfer kinetics with smaller charge transfer resistance (Fig. 2d) and better intrinsic activity (Fig. S4e), demonstrating possible synergistic effect between Ni12P5 and Ni2P during the polymorph structure. The synergistic promotional effect of the heterostructure on the OER performance can be further supported by the results of our DFT simulation given in Fig. 3 , Figs. S8 and S9. On the basis of the structural characterization after the OER process and taking into account the harsh conditions of OER, the surface oxidation of all the catalysts was considered and the OER intermediate species were calculated on the NiOP coordination site (Fig. 3a and b, Figs. S8 and S9). As depicted in Fig. 3c, the rate-determining step for all the simulated samples resides in the transformation from *O to *OOH according to the calculated Gibbs free energy diagram, and the limiting energy barrier (1.29 eV) on the NPPH-O polymorph is lower than that on the bare Ni2P-O (3.29 eV) or Ni12P5-O (3.99 eV) (Fig. S9, Tables S2 and S3). The DFT results show the same trend of OER overpotential as the experimental one (NPPH < Ni2P < Ni12P5). The activity trend can be further explained by calculated values of the d-band center and partial density of state (PDOS) given in Fig. 3d, where the d-band center of Ni at the surface of NPPH-O polymorph is in the middle position, the adsorption energy is neither too strong nor too weak for more favorable adsorption of intermediates during the OER process with respect to the control samples [39]. That is to say, the NPPH-O polymorphic heterostructure could synergistically optimize the valence electron state of active sites as well as the adsorption energy of intermediate species, as should be responsible for its superior OER performance. Encouraged by the extraordinary OER functionality (Fig. 2b) and excellent charge transfer ability (Fig. 2d) of the 1D NPPH heterostructure, we further employ it as the functional support to load single-atom catalysts (SACs). As for simple model illustration, the iridium-based SACs with precursor-calculated weight content of 3 wt% were loaded on the surface of NPPH to obtain Ir/NPPH catalyst by a facile impregnation approach with schematic illustration given in Fig. 4a. As for comparison, the iridium-based SACs with the same weight content were similarly deposited on the surface of CFP to get the Ir/CFP control sample, whose typical morphology, distribution of Ir atoms, and crystal structures are given in Figs. S10-S12, respectively. The successful loading of homogeneous single atoms Ir on the surface of NPPH can be supported by typical HAADF-STEM image (Fig. 4b) and corresponding EDS elemental mapping (Fig. 4c), respectively. Moreover, no obvious Ir nanoparticles in the TEM image (Fig. S13) or XRD diffraction peaks assigned to the Ir particles (Fig. S14) are observed. Interestingly, remarkable synergistic effect between the NPPH and Ir-SACs on the OER activity can be deduced by comparing OER activity of Ir/NPPH with that of NPPH or Ir/CFP (Fig. 4d and e) or by comparing their distinct OER kinetics (Fig. 4f). It should be mentioned that the CFP itself is very poor for water oxidation (Fig. 4d), so the OER activity of Ir/CFP sample is reasonably ascribed to mainly result from the deposited Ir-SAs. To our knowledge, the OER overpotential of Ir/NPPH should be the lowest among the SACs-based alkaline OER electrocatalysts (Table S4). Besides, the Faradaic efficiencies were estimated to be almost 100% ± 5% for both samples (Ir/NPPH, and Ir/CFP), validating the exclusive contribution from OER to the current densities (Fig. S15). Moreover, the Ir/NPPH catalyst exhibits no obviously decreased activity of 50 mA cm−2 at the experimental region of 120 h (Fig. 4g), demonstrating its good alkaline OER stability. The good OER stability can be further confirmed by the similar morphologies and XRD patterns of the Ir/NPPH samples before and after OER stability test (Figs. S16 and S17). Further, XPS results on Ir/NPPH demonstrate that no obvious changes in Ni 2p, P 2p and Ir 4f peaks before and after the OER process except that peak at ∼68 eV for Ni 3p become more stronger due to the oxidized Ni specie (Fig. S18) [40]. It should be noted that the surface Ni–P bonds were transformed to NiOP bonding during the impregnation process for Ir SA incorporation. In contrast, XPS spectra on the Ir/CFP for Ir 4f is obviously different before and after OER process, this could be due to the degradation of active Ir in an alkaline solution by forming water-soluble Ir ions (Fig. S19) [41]. Further synergistic effect between Ni and Ir-SACs in the Ir/NPPH can be evaluated by the results of XPS and X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS). As illustrated in Fig. 5 a, XPS peaks of Ir on Ir/CFT and Ir/NPPH correspond to various valance states including Ir3+, and Ir4+and for Ir/NPPH the peak located at ∼68 eV is from Ni 3p. Further the peak of the Ir 4f spectrum for Ir/NPPH shifts to higher binding energies, suggesting that the Ir species on the surface of Ir/NPPH is at the higher oxidation state. Meanwhile, the introduction of Ir atoms onto the NPPH surface also affects the electronic structure of the NPPH. As can be seen in Fig. 5b, the disappearance of Ni–P characteristic peak in the pure NPPH because of the formation of the NiOP surface oxidation layer after the introduction of Ir atoms and the positive shift in the binding energy in the Ni peaks of suggesting an increased oxidation state of Ni atoms on the surface of Ir/NPPH. Moreover, XPS spectrum of P 2p in Fig. 5c reveals the presence of the Ni–P bond at 129.6 and the NiOP bond at 133.52 eV for pure NPPH. However, for Ir/NPPH, in addition to the NiOP bond at 133.52 eV, a peak at 132.68 eV can also be detected, which could be attributed to the IrOP bond. Similarly, the X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) at the Ir L3-edge of Ir/NPPH shows that the white line intensity peak position is close to IrO2 indicating higher oxidation state of Ir due to the formation of surface IrOP as compared to the Ir/CFP (Fig. 5d) and for the Ir/NPPH, slight shift in Ni K-edge peaks position suggest slightly different oxidization state of Ni than NPPH (Fig. 5e). Further the white line intensity of Ni K-edge peaks (∼8350 eV) decreased in intensity with the introduction of Ir atoms could be related to a distortion of the coordination caused by the incorporation of Ir. Extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) of the Ir foil displays a peak at ∼2.5 Å, corresponding to Ir–Ir bond. However, neither Ir/NPPH nor Ir/CFP showed a peak at 2.5 Å as referred to Ir foil, indicating the mono-dispersed Ir atoms (Fig. 5f). Moreover, the IrO2 displays a peak at 1.57 Å, which corresponds to Ir–O interaction. While the peak of Ir/NPPH appears at ∼1.90 Å, which can be attributed the Ir–P bond. On the whole, XAS and XPS results demonstrate that not only the electronic structure of the single Ir atoms is tuned when it is incorporated on the NPPH, but Ir SACs atoms also tune and modify the electronic structure of Ni atoms. As a result, both Ir active sites and Ni active sites react synergistically to improve the OER performance. The synergistic effect between the NPPH and Ir-SACs can be further supported by the results of our DFT simulation on the Ir/NPPH-O and Ir/CFP (Fig. 6 and Table S5) [6]. The electronic structures of Ir/NPPH-O and Ir/CFP are shown in Fig. 6(a and b), and their successive intermediates (OH, O, and OOH) adsorbed on the catalytic active sites are given in Fig. 6(c and d), respectively. According to the plotted Gibbs free energy diagram (Fig. 6e), the rate-determining step for both Ir/NPPH-O and Ir/CFP resides in the transformation from *O to *OOH, but the limiting energy barrier on Ir/NPPH-O (ca. 0.40 eV) is remarkably lower than that of the Ir/CFP (1.57 eV). Together with energy barrier of NPPH-O catalyst (1.29 eV) given in Fig. 6e and the fact that the activity of Ir/CFP catalyst with CFP inactive mainly results from the Ir-SAs (Fig. 4d), one can reasonably deduce that the synergetic promotion effect on the OER performance of the Ir/NPPH catalyst happens between Ir-SACs and NPPH. It has been also demonstrated that the adsorption of water molecule is the primary and fundamental step, so the surface wettability of catalyst is highly related to its OER performance [42]. Specifically, the superhydrophilic surface has been demonstrated to favor the mass transfer, facilitate the access of electrolytes and/or ensure fast release of gas bubbles during the OER process, resulting in enhanced activity and stability [43,44]. Some phosphides have been reported to exhibit good surface hydrophilicity [45]. So, it renders us to wonder whether the surface wettability of the 1D NPPH heterostructure should be another advantage factor for its good OER performance. For this purpose, the surface wettability of NPPH and CFP were measured for comparison. As illustrated in Fig. S20 and Videos S1-S3, the droplet on the surface of NPPH is immediately spread and adsorbed within 2221 ms (1 ms = 10− 3 s), while the water droplet is pinned on the surface of CFP or bare NF. This demonstrates that the NPPH exhibits much higher surface hydrophilicity with respect to conventional carbon-based support (i.e., CFP) or bare NF, as should be another positive parameter responsible for the outstanding OER performance of Ir/NPPH. 4 Conclusions In summary, we report one novel 1D NPPH polymorphic heterostructure composed of Ni12P5 and Ni2P phases to exhibit superior alkaline OER performance with respect to the corresponding counterparts, and to act as a good support for homogeneous single-atom Ir dispersion. Compared with conventional conducting carbon-based support such as CFP, the 1D NPPH heterostructure not only exhibits similar functionality of charge transfer, but also shows superior surface hydrophilicity. These structural features render it to be a good support for homogeneous single-atom loading. Furthermore, the 1D NPPH heterostructure itself exhibits incomparably excellent OER activity with respect to the CFP, rendering the synergistic promotion effect between NPPH and Ir-SACs to become possible. Accordingly, it is optimistic to expect that the 1D NPPH could be alternative carbon-free functional support used for synergistically promoted electrocatalytic water oxidation. Our results enrich the database of water oxidation materials and may open a new venue for developing highly efficient OER catalysts by employing materials with good catalytic functionality and conductivity as support. coredata.dc:description: Although conducting materials such as carbon nanotube and carbon fiber paper (CFP) have been extensively employed as support of electrocatalytic active sites, most of them are of poor catalytic functionality by themselves and undesirable stability during strong acid/alkaline environments or oxidation process. Here we report a novel one-dimensional (1D) nickel phosphide polymorphic heterostructure (denoted as NPPH) to work as one effective carbon-free functional support for loading of single-atom Ir water oxidation electrocatalyst. Specifically, the NPPH composed of both Ni12P5 and Ni2P phases is not only active for robust alkaline water oxidation but also is of good stability and hydrophilicity for favorable loading of single-atom dispersed iridium. The NPPH supported single-atom Ir electrocatalyst (Ir/NPPH) is found to exhibit remarkably superior water oxidation activity with respect to the NPPH itself or CFP supported single-atom Ir catalyst (Ir/CFP), demonstrating the synergetic promotion effect between NPPH and single-atom Ir catalyst. Furthermore, the NPPH supported single-atom Ir catalyst can bear alkaline water oxidation for over 120 h at current density of 50 mA cm−2. The NPPH developed here is expected as functional support to composite with other water oxidation catalysts, as may be an alternative strategy of developing highly efficient carbon-free electrocatalysts.

coredata.dc:title: One dimensional nickel phosphide polymorphic heterostructure as carbon-free functional support loading single-atom iridium for promoted electrocatalytic water oxidation
